div.style: position: absolute; cursor: n-resize; z-index: 10001; height: 7px; width: 7px; top: -0.5px; left: 259px;

br.span: The health of our students, staff, families, communities and most vulnerable is of utmost importance and we support all efforts to reduce the impact of COVID-19. We will continue to contact you directly through Skyward messaging, email, phone messages, and text as needed.

span.span: Our school buildings are closed for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year under the Governor’s

li.span: Chartwells is providing breakfast and lunch to District families, available for pickup on Tuesdays from 6:30 to 9:30 am at the high school. If you haven’t received any meals but would like to now, please fill out this form.

Please use the tabs below for more information regarding the COVID-19 pandemic and the district's response. Click on the graphic to the right for details on how our staff has adapted to virtual learning.

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_0","title":"Communications","content":"District Communications:



Superintendent's Letter to Parents - 4/17/20



Superintendent's Letter to Parents - 3/30/20



COVID-19 School Closing Letter - 3/13/20



Superintendent's Letter to Parents - 3/12/20 



Health Services Update: 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) - 3/4/20



Health Services Update: 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) - 2/6/20





Talk to your Child:

Some children may be alarmed, confused, or worried about this outbreak. Younger children may not understand news reports they may overhear. Please check in with your child and answer questions they may have. This link from the National Association of School Psychologists website may be helpful if you’re not sure how to discuss this.



You may also find the following comic helpful to teach your child about the virus: 

Just for Kids: A Comic Exploring the New Coronavirus.




Myth Busters: 

Read this advice for the public from the World Health Organization.



Fight Stigma: 

Stigma hurts everyone by creating more fear or anger towards ordinary people instead of the disease that is causing the problem. We can fight stigma and help not hurt others by providing social support

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_1","title":"Virtual Learning","content":"Home Technology FAQ

    
Grades 4K-5: last day of virtual learning is June 5
    
Grades 6-12: last day of virtual learning is June 9
    
No virtual school May 1- teacher professional development day
    
No virtual school May 25- Memorial Day
    
Please direct all technology questions and issues to helpdesk@grafton.k12.wi.us and not your teacher.


Virtual Conferencing Guidelines - Help us insure safe meeting environments for students by following the parenting guidelines.



Grafton High School- Virtual Learning Details

John Long Middle School - Virtual Learning Details

Kennedy and Woodview Elementary - Virtual Learning Details 



Read tips from the WI Department of Public Instruction about learning at home: Every day, Everywhere

 



","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_2","title":"Infection Control","content":"Infection Control Guidelines



Click here for more information from DHS about why your family is Safer at Home.






-The Safer at Home order has been extended to May 26, 2020. Read HERE for more information from the Washington-Ozaukee Public Health Department explaining these measures. 

-Face Covers: The CDC now recommends wearing cloth face covers in public places where social distancing may be more difficult. Please note that surgical masks and N-95 respirators are critical supplies that must be reserved for healthcare workers and first responders. The CDC has provided a fact sheet for wearing face covers.

DHS has also provided face cover information in the FAQ section of their COVID-19 page. 







• STAY HOME when you’re sick. Remain at home for 24 hours after you no longer have a fever.

• Avoid non-essential events and gatherings. Gov. Evers has issued an order prohibiting gatherings of 10 or more people, statewide
• Stay at least 6 feet away from others if you must go out in public.

Video: What You Need to Know About Handwashing (CDC)
-Launder items including washable plush toys as appropriate in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. If possible, launder items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from an ill person can be washed with other people's items.
-If possible use a separate room and bathroom for sick household members.
-To disinfect surfaces, most common EPA-registered household disinfectants will work. See the CDC's recommendations for household cleaning and disinfection.





-Our Directors and District Nurse are working closely with our Facilities Management
Department to ensure that our District is following disease prevention guidelines
set forth by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), Department of Public Instruction (DPI),
the Washington-County Health Department, and DHS.

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_3","title":"Disease Information","content":"Symptoms of COVID-19








**If you develop EMERGENCY WARNING SIGNS for COVID-19, get medical attention immediately. In adults, emergency warning signs can include: 

     Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath

     Persistent pain or pressure in the chest

     New confusion or inability to arouse

     Bluish lips or face

This list is not all-inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning. 






    
How can you tell the difference between Coronavirus, the Flu, a Cold or Seasonal Allergies? Some symptoms are similar between these respiratory illnesses. The chart below can help you figure out if you may be feeling symptoms of allergies or a respiratory illness like COVID-19. If you have a fever and a cough, call your doctor. 




 

COVID-19 Disease Facts



For more information about how COVID-19 spreads, frequently asked questions, and more visit the CDC's website.



Some people are at higher risk of getting sick from COVID-19. This group includes older adults and people with serious chronic medical conditions such as heart disease, diabetes, or lung disease. If you or someone in your household is at a higher risk then follow the recommendations here: CDC - People at Risk for Serious Illness.




Up-to-date Situation Reports:

Washington-Ozaukee Public Health Department

Centers for Disease Control (CDC)

Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS)

World Health Organization (WHO)

John Hopkins Dashboard



The Wisconsin State Lab and the City of Milwaukee Health Department Lab are now able to test for COVID-19. For more information click HERE

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_4","title":"Community & Mental Health Resources","content":"
Local Community Resources:


Family Sharing: Food Pantry & Resale Shop



 

Moraine Lakes Consortium (includes Ozaukee County)

Use the call center to learn more about the application process 1-888-446-1239

Call lines are open: Monday, Tuesday, Thursday 8-4 &  Monday, Friday 10-4

(Note: Your last 30 days of income is used to make eligibility determinations)

https://access.wisconsin.gov/access/

Food Share

Day Care

Medicaid Benefits and BadgerCare Plus

 

Saint Vincent De Paul Society: 262-284-4637

Call and ask to speak to the Store Manager about "emergency assistance." Possible assistance with rent, utilities, transportation, etc.

 

Salvation Army of Ozaukee County: 262-552-6802
leave a message any day of the week

Mondays: Messages are Retrieved
Wednesdays: By Appointment Only

Eligible persons can receive assistance with rent & utilities.





Home Energy Assistance: 262-284-8101
Phone Appointments Only





Allegiant Property Management:

608-790-9226 Call to find out if you qualify for low income housing





COPE Services

262-377-2673 Hotline is open 24/7

https://www.copeservices.org/

Emotional support, Crisis Intervention and resources

 

Advocates Of Ozaukee

24 Hour Crisis Lines 262-284-6902 or 877-375-4034

https://www.advocatesofozaukee.com/

Advocates of Ozaukee is an agency that provides services for those who may be experiencing domestic or sexual violence. Confidentiality is always insured.





Spectrum

844-488-8395 
Offering 2 months of free internet service (if they provide service to your area in general).  

They will return your call if you leave your phone number.





Charter 

Offering 60 days of free internet to households with K-12 and/or college students.
To enroll call 1-844-488-8395. Installation fees will be waived for new student households.





Links from Rogers Behavioral Health:

Six Ways to Calm Anxiety During Times of Uncertainty

Mental Health Resources

Six Tips for Staying Healthy During Social Distancing





Links from Mental Health America-Wisconsin:

Living With Mental Health During COVID-19

Crisis Text Line

National Alliance on Mental Illness COVID-19 Resource Guide





Other Resources:

Financial Resources

Simple Activities for Children and Adolescents

https://www.schoolcrisiscenter.org/resources/covid-19-pandemic-resources/
Supporting Families During COVID-19
5 Ways to Help Teens Manage Anxiety About the Coronavirus
Second Step COVID-19 Support
How to Help Teens Shelter in Place
WHO- Coping with Stress





Grief Resources:

https://www.schoolcrisiscenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/After-a-Loved-One-Dies-English.pdf English

https://www.schoolcrisiscenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/After-a-Loved-One-Dies-Spanish.pdf Spanish

https://www.schoolcrisiscenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/After-a-Loved-One-Dies-Japanese.pdf Japanese




","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_5","title":"Travel Concerns","content":"If you are considering travel please check the CDC Travel Advisory page for more information or talk to your Healthcare Provider. 

	*It is recommended that you do not travel to any country with a Level 3 advisory.

	*We ask that you keep us informed if you are traveling to destinations with any level

	  of advisory for this or other viruses. 

	*Parents, you may be required to keep your child home from school for an extended

         period of time following travel to any country with a Level 2 or higher travel advisory

         for infectious diseases as determined by health department guidelines. 



If you travel to an area where COVID-19 is known to be active, please update your Health Care Provider AND your child's school. You are asked to isolate in your home for 14 days following travel to a sustained community transmission.

 

CDC Travel Advisory page



Frequently Asked Questions for Travelers 



Global Map of Confirmed Cases
